title: Unexplainability of Artificial Intelligence Judgments in Kant's Perspective
abstract:
Kant's Critique of Pure Reason, a major contribution to the
history of epistemology, proposes a table of categories to elu-
cidate the structure of the a priori principle of human judg-
ment. The technology of artificial intelligence (AI), based on
functionalism, claims to simulate or replicate human judg-
ment. To assess this claim, it is necessary to study whether AI
judgment possesses the characteristics of human judgment.
This paper argues that AI judgments exhibit a form that can-
not be understood in terms of the characteristics of human
judgments according to Kant. Because the characteristics of
judgment overlap, we can call this Al's uncertainty. Then, I
show that concepts without physical intuitions are not easy
to explain when their functions are shown through vision.
Finally, I illustrate that even if AI makes sentences through
subject and predicate in natural language, which are compo-
nents of judgment, it is difficult to determine whether AI un-
derstands the concepts to the level humans can accept. This
shows that it is questionable whether the explanation through
natural language is reliable.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Philosophy has explored the concept of human intelligence
for thousands of years, and the study of intelligence is a
traditional philosophical topic. Logic attempts to explain
the structure of knowledge, and epistemology seeks to un-
derstand how knowledge is obtained. In computer science,
the powerful learning capabilities of deep learning (LeCun,
Bengio, and Hinton 2015) have attracted attention. In par-
ticular, artificial neural networks (ANNs) (LeCun, Bengio,
and Hinton 2015) are commonly used to mimic human in-
telligence. However, the information that has been produced
with respect to the type of judgment used by artificial intel-
ligence (AI) remains insufficient. Indeed, the nature of the
judgment made by AI is often considered a black box (Adadi
and Berrada 2018). Philosophy, with its tools to explain and
analyze intelligence, should investigate the mimicry of the
intelligence of ANNs.
First, I examine this topic broadly using Kant's four cat-
egories of judgment to show that unexplainability can oc-
cur in all of them. Then, explainable AI technology is in-
troduced. I then discuss the SoftMax function (Sharma,
Sharma, and Athaiya 2017) that can force AI judgments to
make possibility judgments. Next, the limitations of vision-
based explainable AI technology are examined based on the
fact that concepts whose functions are revealed in vision
but have no physical intuitions are difficult to explain. The
self and self-consciousness are taken as examples. Finally, I
show that even by using natural language processing tech-
nology that reveals subjects and predicates for judgments a
machine makes, it is difficult to determine whether a ma-
chine understands the judgments it makes at a level that a
human would accept. Therefore, this shows that explanation
through natural language processing is not reliable.

sections.title: Background
sections.content:
(Kant 1855), which translated Kant's book into English, is
being used in this work because Kant's Critique of Pure
Reason was not originally written in English. This paper
investigates AI judgments. For this, it is necessary to un-
derstand what judgment is. Judgments are divided in phi-
losophy into subjects and predicates. For example, in the
sentence "Socrates is wise," "Socrates" is the subject, and
"is wise" is the predicate. Basic information about judgment
can be obtained in Kant's discussion of analytic and syn-
thetic judgment (Kant 1855, p. 7).
In all judgments wherein the relation of a subject to
the predicate is cogitated, (I mention affirmative judg-
ments only here; the application to negative will be
very easy,) this relation is possible in two different
ways. Either the predicate B belongs to the subject A,
as somewhat which is contained (though covertly) in
the conception A; or the predicate B lies completely
out of the conception A, although it stands in connec-
tion with it. In the first instance, I term the judgment
analytical, in the second, synthetical. Analytical judg-
ments (affirmative) are therefore those in which the
connection of the predicate with the subject is cog-
itated through identity; those in which this connec-
tion is cogitated without identity, are called syntheti-
cal judgments. The former may be called explicative,
the latter augmentative judgments; because the former
add in the predicate nothing to the conception of the
subject, but only analyse it into its constituent con-

sections.title: Kant
sections.content:
ceptions, which were thought already in the subject,
although in a confused manner; the latter add to our
conceptions of the subject a predicate which was not
contained in it, and which no analysis could ever have
discovered therein. For example, when I say, “All bod-
ies are extended," this is an analytical judgment. For
I need not go beyond the conception of body in order
to find extension connected with it, but merely anal-
yse the conception, that is, become conscious of the
manifold properties which I think in that conception,
in order to discover this predicate in it: it is therefore
an analytical judgment. On the other hand, when I say,
"All bodies are heavy," the predicate is something to-
tally different from that which I think in the mere con-
ception of a body. By the addition of such a predicate
therefore, it becomes a synthetical judgment. Judg-
ments of experience, as such, are always synthetical.
In his exploration of the possibility of synthetic a priori
judgments, Kant intricately maps the capabilities of intelli-
gence, and he illustrates and defines the forms of judgment
(Kant 1855, p. 58).
If we abstract all the content of a judgment, and con-
sider only the intellectual form thereof, we find that
the function of thought in a judgment can be brought
under four heads, of which each contains three mo-
menta.
Based on this claim, he presents Table 1 describing the fea-
tures of judgments. Only through these can our intellect un-
derstand and think."

sections.title: Artificial intelligence
sections.content:
A. M. Turing provided a striking test to assess the question
of whether machines can think which is now known as the
Turing test (French 2000; Turing 2009). According to this,
if a machine provides responses that are indistinguishable
from the way that a human would respond, then the two
should not be differentiated. This aligns with functionalism
(Levin 2004) in the philosophy of mind.
What makes something a thought, desire, pain (or any
other type of mental state) depends not on its internal
constitution, but solely on its function, or the role it
plays, in the cognitive system of which it is a part.
Computer scientists generally and unwittingly adopt func-
tionalist perspectives on the human mind. Many of these
scholars contend that when computers perform human-like
functions, we can recognize them as AI.
As a prominent AI algorithm, ANNs incorporate inter-
connected artificial neurons. Generally, ANNs are trained
to generate correct output values that correspond to certain
given input values. The significance of ANNs as a repre-
sentative algorithm is evident in studies demonstrating their
ability to efficiently train approximate solutions for all func-
tions (Csáji et al. 2001; Hornik, Stinchcombe, and White
1989; Schäfer and Zimmermann 2006; Zhou 2020). This
implies that ANNs can find all functions, and therefore, it
can be assumed that all functions can be computed by using
ANNS.
I would like to emphasize that the process of forward
propagation, through which artificial intelligence makes
judgments, is completely mathematically explained. How-
ever, what judgments are made is not explained like human
judgment. During their training, all of the error contributions
generated by neurons are calculated using a backpropagation
algorithm (LeCun, Bengio, and Hinton 2015), which enables
the ANN to learn by minimizing errors. This backpropaga-
tion algorithm provides information in a readable form using
numbers. However, this form cannot be considered to be the
equivalent of a human judgment. We know why AI makes
judgments in numerical format, but we do not know expres-
sions resembling human judgment. The field that aims to
interpret AI judgments like human judgments is called ex-
plainable AI (Adadi and Berrada 2018).

sections.title: Unexplainability of AI based on Kant's epistemology
sections.content:
When AI makes a judgment, it produces numerical outputs.
For instance, in image classification, let us say that if an im-
age contains a face, the AI outputs 1; otherwise, it outputs
0. However, the determination of whether the judgment cor-
responds to the form of "Universal,” “Particular," or "Singu-
lar" in Table 1 is challenging. For instance, when an ANN
learns to classify a human face, people may require addi-
tional information to distinguish among statements such as
"This image has a human face,” “Some of these types of im-
ages have a human face,” and “All these types of images have
a human face." Human beings' expressions of their judg-
ments are made in their exact form with natural language.

However, AI outputs are represented as numbers. Therefore,
when AI makes a specific judgment, we cannot classify its
form in quantity in Table 1.
In logic, only "Affirmative” (A is B) and “Negative” (A is
not B) are deemed necessary. However, Kant distinguishes
"Infinite" from “Negative” (A is (not B)) (Kant 1855, p. 59).

Figure 1 shows that, although the value of true is defined
as 1 and false as 0, there is no way to know whether AI has
solved a logic problem or a classification problem. ANNs
can solve the problem as a logical problem, as shown in Ta-
ble 2, or as a problem of classification. Thus, we observe
that unexplainability can exist in any of the four categories
of judgment. Inspired by the uncertainty principle in quan-
tum mechanics (Busch, Heinonen, and Lahti 2007), we can
call this AI's uncertainty. In this case, all forms of judgment
overlap.
In the field of explainable AI research, various technolo-
gies are being studied (Adadi and Berrada 2018; Selvaraju
et al. 2017). I believe that by developing technologies that
provide insights into how AI judgments are made, we can
achieve some level of explainability. Computer scientists
have begun revealing which part of an image Al focuses on
when making judgments. These tools assist us in inferring
the subject and predicate. However, neither a subject nor a
predicate is explicitly stated.
Among the four categories that are shown in Table 1,
modality seems easier to put into explainable form than
any of the others. This is because of the SoftMax function
(Sharma, Sharma, and Athaiya 2017), which is applied to the
final layer, ensuring that the cumulative sum of all options
equals 1. This makes outputs satisfy the definition of prob-
ability. For example, when looking at an image and deter-
mining whether there is a dog or a cat, the SoftMax function

makes it possible to indicate a 63% probability that there is
a dog and a 37% probability that there is a cat. According
to Kant, the modality form has the following characteristics
(Kant 1855, pp. 60–61).
The modality of judgments is a quite peculiar func-
tion, with this distinguishing characteristic, that it
contributes nothing to the content of a judgment (for
besides quantity, quality, and relation, there is nothing
more that constitutes the content of a judgment), but
concerns itself only with the value of linking verb in
relation to thought in general.
Because it does not contribute to the content of the judg-
ment, it allows us to explain it in the "Problematical" form
even if we do not know what judgment the machine makes.
Therefore, even before the advent of explainable AI, it was
possible to obtain judgments in the form of “Problematical"
only through the SoftMax function. What we want to know
through explainable AI may be the characteristics of the en-
tire judgment shown in Table 1, but another way is to ar-
tificially consider only the content of the judgment and in-
tentionally fix the modality of the judgment. In other words,
it is not that we will see what kind of judgment was made,
but that we will treat it as a possibility judgment no matter
what judgment was made. People might claim that we can
transform some judgments into possibility judgments. For
example, if something is said to be inevitably and logically
true, the probability is 100%. Can “actually exist,” “neces-
sary," and "possible" be the same? Treating all judgments as
possibility judgments seems problematic."

sections.title: Limitation of vision-based explainable AI
sections.content:
We may encounter a range of things that cannot be explained
when dealing with concepts that have no visual intuitions
but whose functions are revealed in vision. I address this
topic by beginning with an experiment conducted by (Seo
and Lee 2021). To predict the speed of a ball, it is crucial to
observe its movement. However, if the camera that is filming
it also begins to move in the same manner the ball does, the
ball will always appear stationary in the camera's images.
Hence, the position of the camera must also be taken into
account. Coordinate information, such as those provided by
the global positioning system (El-Rabbany 2002) can be uti-
lized in this regard. Moreover, the camera's position can
be estimated by using fixed background information. If the
background screen moves, it means that the camera moves.
If it moves only to a minimal degree, the camera moves only
minimally, Figure 2 provides an image of this scenario.
Performance decreased when boxes were eliminated (Seo
and Lee 2021). This indicates that the AI used boxes to
predict the speed. From this, I conducted additional exper-
iments. Specifically, I seek to demonstrate that the AI uti-
lizes the boxes for information from boxes by employing
Grad-CAM (Selvaraju et al. 2017). Grad-CAM focuses on
a classification problem, so it cannot be used for the task
that predicts the speed itself. Therefore, it is trained to clas-
sify class 1 for high speeds based on the average of final
speeds in the training set and class 2 for low speeds. When

AI predicts speeds higher than the average, I examine where
it focuses on its attention.
I employ a combination of a convolutional neural net-
work (CNN) (Lawrence et al. 1997), which processes two-
dimensional spatial information (e.g., photos), and a long
short-term memory (LSTM) (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber
1997) which processes data obtained along the time axis.
This is called a long-term recurrent convolutional network
(LRCN) (Donahue et al. 2015). The training data comprise
200 videos, each containing 20 images captured at 0.2-
second intervals. The trained model consists of 4 CNN lay-
ers, 2 LSTMs, and 1 fully connected layer (LeCun, Bengio,
and Hinton 2015). If the values in parentheses represent the
input channel, the output channel, the square kernel size, and
the stride in order, the parameters for the CNN layers are
(3,15,5,2), (15,13,5,2), (13,7,5,2), and (7,3,5,2). The LSTM
has two layers and outputs 40 nodes. Finally, the LRCN out-
puts the speed in the last fully connected layer. The learning
rate is set to 1e-4, and Adam (Kingma and Ba 2014) is used.
Cross entropy loss function (Wang et al. 2020a) is employed,
and the learning epoch is set to 2000. Figure 3 presents the
result. I use the activation map of the CNN layer that is first
used in the forwarding process, which processes input val-
ues.
Figure 3 displays the areas where AI focuses on. The area
marked in white is the area that AI focuses on. These white
areas are near the balls and the boxes. This indicates that the
speed of the ball is predicted in relation to the information
from the balls and boxes, as discovered by (Seo and Lee
2021). It is intriguing that even though I only provided the
correct classes for the speed of the ball and the video, the AI
began to give its attention to the balls and boxes, indirectly
utilizing the boxes for self-location.
We could imagine the machine thinking as follows: While
tracking the position of the ball and the box, considering that
my location has moved by this much, the speed is likely to be
at this level. Here, we ask the crucial question: Does the fact
that a machine seeks self-location mean that it understands
the concept of self? Humans address the problem using self-
consciousness. Do machines also have such concepts, based
on functionalism? Problems arise from the following. The
concepts of dogs and cats have physical intuitions. How-
ever, it seems that the concept of self has no such accom-
panying intuitions. Let us investigate the concepts relating
to humans, animals, and AI.
We can think that the structure of human cognition is
the same as each other, assuming no illness is present.
The cognitive structure itself is completely given and be-
comes fully experienced. Research seeks to elucidate how
cognition functions, leading to investigations of epistemol-
ogy and logic. In epistemology, Kant argues for the divi-
sion of self-consciousness into transcendental and empir-
ical aspects. This perspective and other questions persist
in philosophy and in the empirical sciences. First of all,
several attempts have been made to scientifically examine
our self-consciousness. Bodily self-consciousness has been
explored (Blanke 2012; Blanke, Slater, and Serino 2015;
Ionta et al. 2011; Lenggenhager, Mouthon, and Blanke 2009;
Lenggenhager et al. 2007; Serino et al. 2013). In particu-
lar, (Blanke 2012) includes attempts to determine the neural
mechanisms that underlie self-identification, self-location,
and the first-person perspective. The question of whether in-
      dividuals with autism possess the concept of self and how
it can be enhanced has been investigated (Duff and Flat-
tery Jr 2014; Huang et al. 2017; Lind and Bowler 2009;
Lombardo et al. 2007; Mitchell and O'Keefe 2008). On the
other hand, Kant discussed self-consciousness in the follow-
ing paragraph (Kant 1855, pp. 81–83).
The I think must accompany all my representations,
for otherwise something would be represented in me
which could not be thought; in other words, the rep-
resentation would either be impossible, or at least be,
in relation to me, nothing. [...] For the manifold rep-
resentations which are given in an intuition would not
all of them be my representations, if they did not all
belong to one self-consciousness, that is, as my repre-
sentations (even although I am not conscious of them
as such), they must conform to the condition under
which alone they can exist together in a common self-
consciousness, because otherwise they would not all
without exception belong to me. [...] For example, this
universal identity of the apperception of the manifold
given in intuition, contains a synthesis of representa-
tions, and is possible only by means of the conscious-
ness of this synthesis. For the empirical consciousness
which accompanies different representations is in it-
self fragmentary and disunited, and without relation
to the identity of the subject. This relation, then does

not exist because I accompany every representation
with consciousness, but because I join one represen-
tation to another, and am conscious of the synthesis
of them. Consequently, only because I can connect a
variety of given representations in one consciousness,
is it possible that I can represent to myself the iden-
tity of consciousness in these representations; in other
words, the analytical unity of apperception is possible
only under the presupposition of a synthetical unity.
The thought, "These representations given in intu-
ition, belong all of them to me,” is accordingly just the
same as, "I unite them in one self-consciousness, or
can at least so unite them;" and although this thought
is not itself the consciousness of the synthesis of rep-
resentations, it presupposes the possibility of it; that
is to say, for the reason alone, that I can comprehend
the variety of my representations in one conscious-
ness, do I call them my representations, for otherwise
I must have as many-coloured and various a self as
are the representations of which I am conscious.
When a human solves the task given to the AI, it is neces-
sary that all of the intuitions of all images coming in at ev-
ery moment belong to a single self-consciousness. Because,
if I borrow a phrase from Kant, self-consciousness is con-
scious of the synthesis of representations. Therefore, self-
consciousness is needed to solve the task. And the concept
of self is needed for considering self-location.
Animals cannot directly share their experiences with us,
so we are in need of evidence to clarify that they are aware of
the concepts of self and self-consciousness. Kant also grap-
pled with this difficulty (McLear 2011). Animals seem to
have a concept of self. The empirical investigations that have
researched this concept in animals have primarily focused
on self-location. For instance, place cells, which are found
in the hippocampus of mice are known as cells for self-
location (Barry and Burgess 2014; Chen et al. 2019; Danjo,
Toyoizumi, and Fujisawa 2018; Knierim 2015; Nadel and
Eichenbaum 1999). Place cells are activated with respect to
the mouse's location. Specific neurons are activated in spe-
cific spatial positions, and these change as the mouse moves.
Also, Mice acquire self-location through background infor-
mation (Chen et al. 2019). The 2014 Nobel Prize in Phys-
iology or Medicine was awarded for the discoveries of the
cell. I want to emphasize that animals' ability to understand
self-location is not a mere claim but a well-established fact.
These studies might be pieces of evidence that animals pro-
cess temporal and spatial information, implying the exis-
tence of the concepts of self and self-consciousness.
The experiment reported in Figure 3 could help un-
derstand the acquisition of the concept of self and self-
consciousness in humans and animals. This concept appears
to have evolved from the predator-prey relationship. In Fig-
ure 3, we can regard the ball as either the prey or the predator
and the camera as the opposite in each case. This situation
could aid the development of the concepts of self and self-
consciousness. Some studies (Bard et al. 2006; Gallup Jr,
Anderson, and Shillito 2002; Haikonen 2007) have shown
that if an animal can recognize itself in a mirror, it has the
concept of self-consciousness. However, mirrors do not exist
in nature except still water surfaces. I believe that the con-
cepts of self and self-consciousness can be derived from the
relationship between predator and prey.
What sets AI apart from humans and animals is that we
can create its cognition structure to be similar to our own, as
it is a technology we create, not a natural science that must
be verified empirically. This leads us to interpret that AI has
a cognitive structure that resembles ours, even if only par-
tially, provided that sufficient conditions are provided. These
characteristics can lead to attaching the word "Artificial" to
an existing concept. Explainable AI involves a long journey
that involves identifying the parts of AI that align with hu-
man cognition and striving to make it similar to ours. How-
ever, Al researchers are not obligated to always make AI
explainable.
Based on this generous attitude, previous investigations
(Bringsjord et al. 2015; Chella, Frixione, and Gaglio 2008;
Zhang and Zhou 2013) have argued that machines have self-
consciousness. However, we cannot have any confidence in
the concepts that do not have visual intuitions. These con-
cepts could be explainable in other ways, but they cannot
be interpreted in a vision-based explainable way. We can
only confidently conclude that there is a relationship be-
tween these and other parts. Even if vision-based explain-
able technology develops, it cannot explain anything about
concepts that appear in vision but do not have physical intu-
itions.
We can emphasize that AI is created to perform specific
tasks. In natural language processing, the chat of AI is an
important topic. When a certain sentence is inputted, the AI
outputs a response (Deng et al. 2019; Zhou et al. 2018). Re-
cent technologies have displayed chatbots that can pass the
Turing test. Nevertheless, we do not assert that chatbots have
self-consciousness. They are just set up to behave that way.
Using human chat data, AI is trained to output appropriate
sentences. As another example, a generative adversarial net-
work consists of a discriminator and a generator (Creswell

sections.content:
et al. 2018; Goodfellow et al. 2014). Here, the generator pro-
duces random fake data, and the discriminator is responsible
for distinguishing between the real and the fake data. Mak-
ing them compete with each other, we train the generator
to produce data that are as similar to real data as possible.
For another example, reinforcement learning studies how an
agent adapts to the environment through changing actions
and states after dividing a system into an agent and environ-
ment (Mazyavkina et al. 2021; Sutton and Barto 2018). Both
cases involve humans dividing two groups in advance and
making them interact. I doubt whether these computer pro-\
